Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?

Comments_List: Different types of modeling, linking different scales and translating biochemical/mechanical phenomenon into mathematical equations
How to do multiscale modelling for a variety of biological scales and systems. Broad range of skills acquired.
I learned more about the components and programs that constitute the building of multiscale models without feeling lost, which is something that cannot be said of every Yale STEM class.

This was a great class to introduce me to multiscale modeling of biomechanical systems. I learned the reasons behind making a model and why models are useful. I learned how to implement models using Matlab and Continuity.
Insight into how multiscale models are constructed, an appreciation for the work involved in building useful models
Really enjoyed the lab sessions and being able to work directly with the code under Stuart's watch. Stuart was super willing to explain even basic things and to provide extra help
Strengths: Amount of freedom to explore. Allows you to learn so so much.

This course made difficult material relatively reasonable to grasp, and the homework assignments were always relevant to the material being taught in class. Prof. Campbell genuinely wanted everyone to do well and did a great job of checking in on everyone's progress.

The class does really well in guiding you step by step through implementing a multiscale model. I really enjoyed the structure of the modules as well. The first day was a lecture that introduced you to the type of model or system to be model. The next two classes were workdays where Prof. Campbell would walk around assisting us through the model building. On the fourth day of the module, we would have a literature review, which helped us to develop our scientific literacy.
Yes! A great, not too stressful class with a good professor, hands on exercises and interesting material
Definitely. Fun class, very well-done. Youll learn a lot and get a chance to explore and model and analyze a system youre interested in, as well as acquire the skills to do it.
Yes--this course is great for advancing your understanding of computational modeling and integration with biological systems in a way that isn't too overwhelming.

I would highly recommend this class to another BME senior. At this point, it's a great way to put together everything you've learned into a really cool process of model building. Professor Campbell's lab activities guide you through step-by-step through the process in a way that helps you to understand what is going on and the reason for doing those steps. The workload is manageable and the class really does facilitate learning.
yes, great professor, interesting content, the final modeling project was a good challenge
